Description: Terracotta seated devotee of Isis with puppy. A devotee of Isis seated with a puppy on her lap. She wears a long tunic and a mantle, halfknotted at her breast, and her hair is parted in the centre with smooth locks on each side. Her right hand is raised to the side of her head, holding a strand of hair away from it; her left hand rests on the back of the puppy. She crosses her legs at the ankles and rests her feet on a footstool. The seat has a smoothly rounded back (otherwise the rear is plain). There is no plinth. Hollow; two-piece mould; the underside is sealed. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with minute traces of a white dressing.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close and near: Allen 1985: nos 74 and 75 (but no puppy?), from Karanis, dated late third to first half of fourth century ad, and no. 76, dated to the Severan period or later, it is suggested that she holds castanets in her raised right hand; Dunand 1979: no. 110; Heide and Thiel 2004: 83, no. ii.2.10, dated Hellenistic; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 78.1; Perdrizet 1921: no. 397, from the Fayum; Weber 1914: no. 373, acquired in the Fayum = Philipp 1972: fig. 35, dated c. ad 180–200 (interpreted by Weber and Philipp as a woman with a lap-dog, adjusting her hair); and see the well-modelled bejewelled fragment Weber 1914: no. 378, said to be from the Fayum.
